title: Phone Book Typography
content:
Hi

I'm to be working soon on an optimization of fonts to be used in a phone book listing. I'd greatly appreciate any information that could help me regarding legibility at small sizes and a selection of potential fonts.

We are using Bell Centennial right now, but might well decide to change.  
Whitney, Martin Majoor's Janszen, ... suggestions will be most appreciated!
author: Martin LAllier

comments.content: I'd think a slightly condensed sans would be clearer, a la Univers or Franklin Gothic. I'd think serifs would be harder to read at phone-book sizes.

I read about H&FJ's Retina being suitable for this type of situation. But it's probably exclusive to some organization since I can't seem to find it on their site. Have you looked at the [Freight Micro family](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123173803/http:/www.joshuadarden.com/shop/freightmicro.php)?

You can get more information on Retina by contacting Hoefler Frere-Jones directly, they sent me a beautiful specimen for it.

There's also a [press release](http://web.archive.org/www.typography.com/press/pr_04_09_02.html) for Retina on the HFJ website

[Dalton Maag](http://web.archive.org/web/20150123173803/http:/www.daltonmaag.com/about/commissioning/case_studies/bt_directory.html) designed a custom face for the BT in the UK.

I thought there were some PDF samples there, but the site seems to have been updated.
Bell Centennial is still a great font - even works as funky display face - love those ink traps.

I have sent you an email via your website address.

—K
